abstract: Searches for “Tiananmen,” “Falun Gong” and “corruption” increased by more than 10 times in Hong Kong on the day that Google began offering uncensored Chinese-language search results.
snippet: Searches for “Tiananmen,” “Falun Gong” and “corruption” increased by more than 10 times in Hong Kong on the day that Google began offering uncensored Chinese-language search results.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — Chinese searches for politically delicate terms peaked the day Google stopped filtering its search results, but the government pressed on with a campaign to remove online praise of the company.

headline.main: After Google’s Move, a Shift in Search Terms
headline.print_headline: After Google’s Move, a Shift in Search Terms

byline.original: By Jonathan Stray and Lily Lee
